questions.text: Shenton line is seen in X-ray of :
questions.solution: D Ref.: Apley's system of orthopaedics and fractures 9/e p354

questions.text: Judet view of X-ray is for :
questions.solution: A Ref.: https://www.wikiradiography.net/page/judet+views

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in lower limb
questions.solution: C Ref.: https:// en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_orthopedics Dunlop traction is used in treatment of supracondylar fracture of humerus in children. Skin traction is applied to the forearm after painting the skin with compound benzoin tincture. The vertical counter-traction for the humerus, proximal to the fracture site, has usually been achieved by a wide piece of adhesive felt to which a small weight is applied

questions.text: Jersey finger is caused by rupture of
questions.solution: A Ref.: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/jeresy_finger A Jersey finger is a traumatic rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon at its point of attachment to the distal phalanx. This injury often occurs in American football when a player grabs another player's jersey with the tips of one or more fingers while that player is pulling or running away.

questions.text: Removal of vertebral disc can be done by all these approaches except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref.: Wikipedia , medscape Indications of laminoplasty • Compressive myelopathy and radiculopathy due to cervical spondylosis • prolapse intervertebral disc ossified posterior longitudinal ligament/thickened or calcified ligamentum flavum • Prolapse cervical disc with predominantly radicular symptoms • Tumors • infective lesions • comminuted fractures involving the posterior vertebral elements and impinging into the spinal canal • To gain surgical access to intraspinal pathology like tumors, infective granulation, abscess, or syringomyelia • In extended laminectomy (including c2 and sometimes ca): As subsequent hyperlordosis cause posterior migration of spinal cord, hence tension on nerve root and blood vessel in young patients, as predisposition to kyphosis is high

questions.text: A young patient is diagnosed to haveirrepairable tear of the rotator cuff. Treatment of choice will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: https://orthoinfo.aaos.org/topic.cfm? Topic= A00504 https://www.orthop.washington.edu/? Q+patient -care / articales /shoulder / reverse- shoulder - replacement . html

questions.text: Investigation of choice in stress fracture
questions.solution: A Ref.: The encyclopedia of sports Medicinep g772 Stress fractures refer to fractures occurring in the bone due to a mismatch of bone strength and chronic mechanical stress placed upon the bone. MRI is the most sensitive modality for diagnosis of a stress fracture and is an important tool to distinguish high and low-risk fractures to help clinicians for management plans and a sensitivity reported to reach close to 100%

questions.text: In osteoporosis which of these is seen
questions.solution: C Ref.: Harrison's principles of internal medicien 18/e Chap 354 https:// labtestsonline.org / understanding / conditions/osteoporosis/start/1 Decreased bone density can be appreciated by decreased cortical thickness and loss of bony trabeculae in the early stages in radiography. Bones like the vertebra, long bones (proximal femur), calcaneum and tubular bones are usually looked at for evidence of osteoporosis. Nevertheless, dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is the gold standard of diagnosing osteoporosis

questions.text: A 9 – years-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect?A 9 – years-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect?
questions.solution: a. Supracondylar Fracture Ref: Apley’s System of orthopedics and Fractures9/e p 371, 760

questions.text: Identify the deformity seen in the given picture: (Color Fig. 16)
questions.solution: b. Hallux valgus Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p604 Hallux valgus is a progressive foot deformity in which the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint is affected and is often accompanied by significant functional disability and foot pain.

questions.text: The following diagram demonstrates which of the following tests being performed on the patient? ( Color Fig. 17)
questions.solution: a. Thomas test Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p 495 Test Positioning: Subject les supine with both knees fully flexed against chest and buttocks near the table edge Examiner stands with one hand on subjects lumbar spine of iliac crest to monitor lumbar lordosis or pelvic tilt. Action: Subject slowly lowers test leg until leg is fully relaxed or until either anterior pelvic tilting or an increase in lumbar lordosis occurs Positive Finding: Lack of hip extension with knee flexion greater than 45 degrees is indicative of iliopsoas tightness. Full hip extension with knee flexion less than 45 degrees is indicative of rectus femoris tightness Hip external rotation during any of the previous scenario is s indicative of IT band tightness

choices.text: Fracture of the surgical neck of humerus

questions.text: All the following can lead to damage of the axillary nerve except:
questions.solution: b. Improper use of crutches Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p 282 Axillary nerve lesion Causes a. Fracture of surgical neck of humerus b. Inferior dislocation of shoulder joint c. Misplaced injection into deltoid Muscles involved : Deltoid and Teres minor Manifestations: • Loss of abduction from 18 to 90 • Shoulder weakness • As the deltoid atrophy, the rounded contour of the shoulder is lost and becomes flattened compared to the uninjured side. Sensory loss Injury of the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm leads to loss of skin sensation over the lower half of deltoid muscle

questions.text: A child presented with pain in the forearm following a trauma. An AP and Lateral X-ray of the forearm reveal the findings as shown . What is the most likely diagnosis? (color Fig.18)
questions.solution: d. Galeazzi’s fracture Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p 771

choices.text: Commonly Present In the 20-40 years age group
Matrix Consists Of Proliferating Mononuclear Cells
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
It is benign tumor which may have lung metastasis

questions.text: About Giant cell tumor, all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor It is seen in 20-40 years age group, benign but locally aggressive with uncertain origin (Monocyte macrophage lineage). Although benign, rarely it can have lung metastasis.

questions.text: What is the eponym for the fracture shown below:
questions.solution: C monteggiafracture Ref:Apley’ssystemoforthopaedicsandfractures9/ep771

questions.text: The following pelvic X Ray Was Seenina Patient all the following signs will be present except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gaenslen’stest Ref: Appley’ssystemoforthopaedicsfracture9/ep499 Vascular sign of narath is absence of femoral artery pulsations.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with hip pain for Last 6 Months .Hip X-ray shown below. What is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: A Giantcelltumor RefApley’ssystemoforthopaedicsandfractures9/e p202,215 spotter Multiple myeloma- commonly seen in older age group atleast around 60 years of age. -Simple bone cyst will be a well defined radiolucent lesion commonly seen in bones of upper limb and in an age group of 10-20. -An adamantinoma is a rare low-grade malignant bone tumor typically found in the diaphyses of long bones in 20-40 year olds. So by ruling out options , answer would be A) GCT

questions.text: 24 Year old male presents with a humerus fracture shown in the figure below: Which is the erv likely to be involved by the fracture
questions.solution: B Radialnerve Ref: Apley’ssystemoforthopaedicsand Fractures9/e p760 Radial Nerves lie anterior to the supracondylar humerus region they are at risk for injury, primarily post-trauma either by stretching, piercing or impinging at the fracture ends or being entrapped between two fracture fragments (traumatic or primary nerve injury)

choices.text: Congenital Pseudo Art Is of Tibia

questions.text: The following deformity is seen in child.What is the likely cause:
questions.solution: C Congenital Pseudo Art Is of Tibia Ref: Apley’ssystemoforthopaedicsand fractures9/e p185 Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia (CPT) refers to nonunion of a tibial fracture that develops spontaneously or after a minor trauma. A pseudarthrosis is defined as a “false joint” and is a break in the bone that fails to heal on its own. The pseudarthrosis usually develops within the first two years of life.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma centre. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of movements. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. What type of deformity is seen in the patient?
questions.solution: b. Anterior dislocation of hip Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg 846

questions.text: A 12 years old boy Presented with pain in his right hip. A pelvic X-ray was taken and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Osteogenesisimperfecta Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg 173 It is genetically heterogeneous group of collagen disorders. It is also known as brittle bones disease/ fragilitas ossium. It results from a defect of type I collagen production (major protein of bone matrix) that leads to congenital osteopenia with increased bone fragility, low bone mass, and other connective tissue manifestations like dental abnormalities, lax joints, thin skin. It is a heritable condition of connective tissue.

questions.text: The following x-ray was taken of a 16 years old. What is the pathology seen?
questions.solution: c. Chronic Osteomyelitis Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e g 33 It is a result of osteonecrosis caused by disruption of intraosseous and periosteal blood supply during the acute stage of the disease. A dead infected bone fragment becomes separated from viable bone (known as a sequestrum). Infective agents within the devascularised sequestrum become protected from antibiotics and the endogenous immune response, forming a nidus for chronic infection. This may persist for years. Inhomogeneous osteosclerosis and/or sequestrum formation (necrotic bone) is characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis on plain radiography

questions.text: Which of the following increases callus formation (Not cartilage?)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Movement at fracture site Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg 689: NyaryTamas, Scamell BE. (2015). Principles of bone and joint injures and therir healing. Srugery (Oxford). 33 (1), pg 7-14. Fracture healing : A) Primary B) Secondary Primary fracture healing: Primary healing occurs when bone ends are in approximation to each other - No movement at #site - No callus seen . Takes time. Secondary Fracture healing: - Callus is formed - Micromovement stimulates callus formation. -Small amount of motion ( micromovements ) and weight bearing at the fracture causes a soft callus to form leading on to secondary bone formation.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed?
questions.solution: a. Tension band wiring Ref: Apley’s system of ORthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg887-888 The tension band technique converts a tensile force into a compressive force. Enables improved fracture healing, as stability is improved when tensile forces are reduced at the fracture site.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the abnormality seen in the wrist X-ray from a 12-year-old boy as shown below?
questions.solution: a.Rickets Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg 136 Radiographic features In the growing skeleton, the deficiency of normal mineralization is most evident at metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification where there is an excess of non-mineralized osteoid resulting in growth plate widening and abnormal configuration of the metaphysis: • fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis • splaying: widening of metaphyseal ends • cupping: concavity of metaphysis 6 It is not surprising that these features are most prominent at the bones where growth is greatest: • knee: distal femur, proximal tibia • wrist: especially the ulna 1 • anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary As osteomalacia co-occurs with rickets, it is important to remember that even bones that appear mineralized are weak and result in bowing, most commonly seen in the lower limbs once the child is walking. The legs bow outwards with variable deformity of the hips (both coxa vara and coxa valga are seen 1). Other bone deformities are also noted such as genu valga and vara as well as protrusio acetabuli 6. The lower ribs may also be drawn inwards inferiorly by the attachment of the diaphragm (Harrison's sulcus).

questions.text: The following deformity shown in the picture is likely to be a complication of which of these?
questions.solution: a. Supracondylar fracture Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e pg 371, 760

questions.text: March fracture in metatarsal following stress in seen in _____ of second metatarsal
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neck Various text books give different answers. So compiling all references and we will go for the best. Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 1 March fracture: Fatigue fracture of the SHAFT of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 88 Military recruits in their first few weeks of training also are vulnerable to so-called march fractures. Patients often note the gradual onset of pain directly over the second metatarsal NECK region 2 to 4 weeks after beginning a running or aerobics program. Rockwood & Green’s Fractures in Adults, 6th Edition, Chapter 21 Metatarsal stress fractures are common in distance runners and ballet dancers. The second metatarsal NECK is the most likely site for stress fracture, but all metatarsals are susceptible. Since both Cambell and Rockwood favours the Neck of metatarsal we would like to go with that. Maheshwari textbook of orthopaedicsfavours shaft though.

questions.text: In polio paralysis; hand, knee gait due to weakness of: POLIOMYELITIS In poliomyelitis; hand to knee gait is the sum of quadriceps weakness and fixed knee flexion deformity.
questions.solution: (c) Quadriceps Ref. Apleyorthopaedics. Page 9th edition pg. 974 MECHANISM: Normally to transmit weight of lower limb during midstance, the knee is locked by quadriceps contraction. If it is weak (as in polio) locking is hampered and buckling at knees will occur. Therefore to stabilise the knee for weight bearing, the patient places his hand in front of the knee and lower thigh region. HAND TO KNEE GAIT

questions.text: A 4-years-old boy fell on outstretched hand, X-ray is as shown below. Which of the following vessel is most commonly affected? Refer Colour Plate 51
questions.solution: (c) Brachial artery Ref. Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 14 Rockwood & Green’s Fractures in Children, 6th Edition – Chapter 14 Injury to the brachial artery: This is a complication commonly associated with a displace supracondylar fracture. The brachial artery is usually injured by the sharp edge of the proximal fragment. Supracondylar fracture: Most common type in chidren – extension type Three point relation maintained Named signs – S shaped deformity, dimple sign, fish tail sign, crescent sign, tear drop sign, fat pad sign Malunion – Cubitusvarus deformity (gunstock deformity) Optimum time to carry out corrective surgery for malunion-6 months Surgery for gunstock deformity – French Osteotomy MC injured nerve in supracondylar fracture of humerus (overall) – Anterior interosseous nerve Extension type – Anterior interosseous nerve Flexion type – Ulnar nerve Most common artery involved – Ulnar artery Classification of supracondylar fracture – Garland classification GUN STOCK DEFORMITY

choices.text: Flexed and adducted and internally rotated

questions.text: An elderly patient slipped in bathroom and sustained injury over hip. X-ray is shown below. Her attitude of leg will be “The physical examination typically reveals the following: External rotation of the leg, the patella facing outwards. Shortening of the leg, usually slight. Tenderness in the groin. Attempted hip movements painful, and associated with severe spasm. Active straight leg raising not possible.” Classification of neck of femur fracture: Depending on the site Subcapital Incidence -70% Just below the head at site of epiphyseal plate Transcervical 20% of the fracture Fracture line runs across the neck of femur Basal 10% of the fractures. Fracture line runs at the origin of neck
questions.solution: (a) Shortened abducted and externally rotated Ref. Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 55 Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 18 Clinical Signs and Symptoms History – Trivial trauma (slip and fall on bathroom, with pain at hip and unable to move) Attitude of limb – flexion abduction and external rotation Examination –tenderness at mid-inguinal point Following trivial/severe trauma a patient develops severe pain in the attitude of the limb) Minimal shortening is observed. There is tenderness over the mid inguinal point The greater trochanter is normal and non-tender We have included the exact attitude of limb as described in Cambell’sorthopaedics above. Potential future image based question: Austin Moore Prosthesis

questions.text: Which of the position is being tested in the picture given below? Refer Colour Plate 53)
questions.solution: (b) External rotation Ref. Postgraduate companion in orthopaedics. By Biswas Page. 74 This is a simple question to assess the examination skills of a medical graduate. Enlisting below the muscles involved in various movement of HIP Flextion – Iliopsoas, rectus femoris, Sartorius Extension – Gluteus maximus, semimembranosus, semitendinosus and biceps femoris Abduction – Gluteus medius, gluteus minimus and the deep gluteals (piriformis, gemelli, etc.) Adduction – Adductors longus, brevis and magnus, pectineus and gracillis Lateral rotation – Gluteus medius and minimus, semitendinosus and semimembranosus The degree to which flexion at the hip can occur depends on whether the knee is flexed – this relaxes the hamstring muscles, and increases the range of flexion. Limitation of extension of HIP joint ® the joint capsule and the iliofemoral ligament. Potential Image based question in regards with hip joint: Supporting Ligaments

choices.text: Normal shoulder healing and normal movements

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common squeal of traumatic dislocation of shoulder? DISLOCATION OF SHOULDER AND SQUEAL “Most common early complication of Anterior Dislocation is – NERVE INJURY (CIRCUMFLEX BRANCH OF AXILLARY NERVE > AXILLARY NERVE) Most common complication is Recurrent dislocation (50% of all shoulder dislocations recurrently dislocate) SHOULDER DISLOCATION Shoulder dislocation can be anterior or posterior. Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common amounting to approximately 98% Anterior Dislocation of the Shoulder Mechanism: Hyperabduction and external rotation strain.The deltoid bulge is lost and it appears as a hollowDugas test: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder.Hamilton Ruler TestA ruler is placed from the acromian and lateral condyle, because of the deltoid bulge it’s not possible to make the points in a line. In case of dislocation it’s possible to touch the both points in a line. Reduction of Dislocation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Recurrent dislocation of shoulder Ref. Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 60 Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 13 Rockwood & Green’s Fractures in Adults, 6th Edition, Chapter 34 A-Kocher method B-Old Hippocratus method Posterior Dislocation Mechanism: A powerful adduction internal rotation strain, e.g. in seizures, electric shock or sometimes a direct posterior impact on the shoulder. Types Subacromial Subglenoid Supraspinous X-ray Findings X-ray: In an undislocated shoulder there is a overlap of head of humerus and the glenoid. This overlap is lost in case of dislocation Empty glenoid sign: Due to dislocation the glenoid is no more holding the head of humerus, and it appears empty. Demptyglenoid sign in posterior dislocation

choices.text: Interossesous membrane tear with ulnar shaft fracture
Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseousmembrance tear with radial shaft fracture
Interosseous membrane tear with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) tear and ulnar shaft fracture
Interosseous membrane tear with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Gallezi fracture dislocation? GALLEZI FRACTURE DISLOCATION “Dislocation or subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint in association with a solitary fracture of the radius at the junction of the middle and distal third” “Fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint” “Distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) injury” (Gives Piano Key Sign) Primary stabilizers of DRUJ are: Volar and dorsal radioulnar ligaments TFCC If DRUJ is Disrupted – TFCC can get injured TFCC (triangular fibrocartilage complex) Contributes to the Stability of ELBOW Volar Compenents Volar radioulnar ligament Ulnotriquetral ligament Ulnolunate ligament Ulna components Triangular ligament Ulna collateral ligament Meniscal homologue Dorsal components Dorsal radioulnar ligament Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon sheath
questions.solution: (d) Interosseous membrane tear with triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) tear and radial shaft fracture Ref. Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 57 Rockwood & Green’s Fracture in Adults, 6th Edition, Chapter 27 POTENTIAL FUTURE QUESTION Piano-Key sign: DRUJ instability

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold pen and he was not able to hold paper between fingers. Which of the following site given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? Refer Colour plate 54 First we will analyse the symptoms and signs one by one Inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, Suspect Ulnar Nerve Involvement CANNOT HOLD PEN Intrinsics of hand affected (musicians nerve, fine movements) suspect ulnar nerve This is not Pen Test used for median nerve palsyNot able to hold paper between fingers. Think Card Test (Palmar interossei supplied by ulnar nerve)So concluding, the most probable nerve injured in this case is Ulnar nerve.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref. Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 10; Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 62, 68 Now we will look at the picture. The points marked A,B,C,D and the nerves passing across them. Which of the following site given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question> A-neck of Humerus – Axillary Nerve B-Shaft of Humerus – Radial Nerve D- Medial Epicondyle – Ulnar Nerve So the answer would be D – Medial epicondyle. The mark C ® lateral epicondyle causes tardy ulnar nerve palsy ® as a sequel to non-union. Keeping in mind lateral condyle fracture are relatively rare compared to medial condyle we go for it.

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of patella fracture? This is a repeat and straight forward question. We will look at patellar fractures below:
questions.solution: (b) Tension band wiring Ref. Essential Orthopaedics and Trauma (Fifth Edition) Chapter 14; Essential Orthopaedics – J. Maheshwari Chapter 20; Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 54 Transvers fractures (in our case) The patella can be split transversely be indirect violence, e.g. a sudden violent contraction of the quadriceps, gives rise to a fracture with the fracture line running transversely across the patella, dividing it into two. These injuries split not only the patella but also the quadriceps expansions on either side. Left untreated, the fragements separate widely and quadriceps function is lost. Treatment Internal fixation is required. A TENSION BAND WIRE is usually adequate. Comminuted Fractures The patella is fractured by a blow directly to the knee, often in a road traffic accident Treatment Fragments cannot be accurately reassembled. It is best to remove the patella – PATELLECTOMY

questions.text: Which of the following is bone holding forceps used in orthopaedic surgeries? Refer Colour plate 55 This is again to test the clinical acumen of MBBS graduate. Naming of the instruments above: a. Babcock forceps b. Bone-holding forceps c. Reduction forceps d. Hack saw blade Last AIIMS had a question on general surgical instruments. Gradually AIIMS is shifting not only to test the memory of students also by judging the overall acumen of a medical graduate. Looks like a positive sign J
questions.solution: (b) B Ref. Hand book of orthopaedic examinations. Page. 204

questions.text: Haglund deformity is seen in which of the following joints: HAGLUND DEFORMITY (PUMP BUMP) AND RETROCALCANEAL BURSITIS Is caused by chronic inflammation of the adventitious superficial pretendinous Achilles bursa (that separates the Achilles tendon from the overlying skin). Bursitis usually is caused by chronic irritation from a shoe heel, modification of shoe wear usually relieves symptoms.This deformity usually occurs in young women in their twenties or thirties Treatment: Conservative If conservative measures fail then Calcaneal osteotomy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ankle Ref. Essential Orthopaedics and Trauma (Fifth Edition) Chapter 25; Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics Twelfth Edition – Chapter 82

choices.text: Repeated tiny movements at the fracture site

questions.text: The growth of cartilage following fracture will be increased by which of the following: This is a direct repeat question from previous AIIMS The mechanical stability of the fracture site influences the repair process.
questions.solution: (d) Repeated tiny movements at the fracture site Ref. Mercer’s Textbook of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Chapter 19, Page 270 Primary fracture healing occurs where fracture haematoma is not disturbed, as in cases treated non-operatively or Operated with Relative stability (fractures operated without disturbing the fracture haematoma), which allows for micro movements at the fracture site. There is healing, with callus formation. Micro movement at the fracture site stimulate Callus Formation FACTORS AFECTING FRACTURE HEALING Blood Supply Soft tissue injury Radiation Chemical or thermal burns Infection Anaemia& hypoxia Denervation Excessive compression (more than 30Ibs) Age Excessive Movement Inadequate immobilisation Inadequate fixation or compliance Gap Intact fellow bone Interposed soft tissue Distraction of bones Other Nutrition (Vit C required for normal collagen) Drugs (corticosteroids inhibit osteoblast differentiation)

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
Talocalcaneonavicular joint is which type of synovial joint?
questions.solution: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint: the rounded head of the talus being received into the concavity formed by the posterior surface of the navicular, the anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?

choices.text: Open wound with fracture with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as 3B according to Gustillo Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury?
1st Carpal bone to ossify:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Capitate List of carpal bones and time of appearance of ossification centre : -Capitate : 2 months - Hamate : 3 months-1 year - Triquetral : 3 years - Lunate : 4 years - Scaphoid : 5 years - Trapezium &Trapezoid : 5-6 years - Pisiform : 9-12 years

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Specific staging system (Ficat staging) exists for the hip which includes x-ray, MRI and bone scan appearances, and covers much of the imaging appearances, thus please refer to that article. Other than describing the general appearance of the affected region, the following are necessary to include in the report as they have a bearing on prognosis and treatment: • position • estimating percentage volume of the head involved (axial) and percentage weight-bearing surface involved (coronal) • coexisting osteoarthritis or secondary degenerative change • joint effusion • presence of a potentially unstable osteochondral fragment: rim sign • subchondral fractures

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer(B) - Compartment syndrome can be diagnosed early by high index of Suspicion. Excessive pain , not relieved with usual doses of analgesics in a patient with compartment syndrome must raise an alarm . Stretch test : This is the earliest sign of impending compartment syndrome. The ischaemia muscles, when stretched , give rise to pain . ( Eg : Passive extension of wrist &fingers produces pain in flexor compartment of Forearm) This is the most important criteria for compartment syndrome . Clinical features: 6Ps A) Pain on passive stretch B) Puffiness /Swelling C) Pallor D) Paresthesia E) Paralysis F) Pulselessness Manometry: Measures the pressure inside compartment ( Normally : <10mm Hg) A pressure > 30 mm Hg of the diastolic pressure is indicative of Compartment Syndrome Reference: Essential Orthopaedics Maheshwari ( 6th edition) Pg:47

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is the main restraint to internal rotation
It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL?
questions.solution: The PCL tear may give a false Lachman's test due to posterior subluxation. Test is done with the patient in supine position and the knee is flexed to 90 degrees. The examiner stabilizes the foot. Next the examiner pushes backwards on the tibia, looking for the tibia to sag posteriorly.

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:
questions.solution: Glucosamine and chondroitin protect cells called chondrocytes, which help maintain cartilage structure. In theory, these supplements have the potential to slow cartilage deterioration in the joints, and to reduce pain in the process

choices.text: Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board
Strap the patients head thorax & pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position
Turn the patient to one side
Assess the patient by asking his name

questions.text: While attending to a victim of RTA, who is otherwise conscious, all the following can be done except?
questions.solution: The patient need not be turned to one side as risk of aspiration is least in an otherwise conscious patient

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight this is known as:
questions.solution: Hoover Test: Test Position • Patient supine • Examiner at feet of patient with hands cupping the calcaneus of each leg Action: • Patient attempts to active straight leg raise on the involved side Positive Findings • Patient does not attempt to lift the leg and examiner does NOT sense pressure from the uninvolved leg pressing down on the hand • Patient is not attempting to perform the test

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except-
questions.solution: Patients with Sprengel deformity often have one or more of the following abnormalities and conditions: • Klippel-Feil syndrome • spina bifida • kyphoscoliosis • torticollis • underdevelopment of clavicle or humerus These possible co-existing anomalies need to be looked for in any patient presenting with Sprengel deformity.

questions.text: A 55-years-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a H/o. Intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: C No h/o fever rules out pott’s spine No h/o weight loss rules out malignancy Hence here the answer becomes cauda equina syndrome

questions.text: What is the treatment modality for the following fracture?
questions.solution: A The image shows patellar fracture in which superior fragment is pulled up by quadriceps tendon and inferior fragment is pulled up by ligamentum patellae.Here the fragments are being pulled apart by shearing forces which has to be united using compressive forces. Hence tension band wiring needs to be done.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution: C Thumb has only one interphanageal joint which is flexed by FPL ( flexor pollicis longus) . this muscle is supplied by AIN ( anterior interosseous nerve)

questions.text: Which bone doesn't form wrist joint?
questions.solution: B Wrist joint is formed by the articulation of scaphoid, lunate and triquetral bones with radius. Ulna is kept outside the wrist joint by articular disc

questions.text: A 12-years-old boy presents with chronic knee pain for 2 years. Knee X-ray is shown. Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution: B Primary osteosarcoma typically occurs in young patients (10-20 years) with 75% taking place before the age of 20 because the growth centers of the bone are more active during puberty/adolescence 3. There is a slight male predominance. Secondary osteosarcoma occurs in the elderly, usually secondary to malignant degeneration of Paget disease, extensive bone infarcts, post-radiotherapy for other conditions, osteochondroma, and osteoblastoma.

questions.text: Peak incidence of osteosarcoma occurs at:
questions.solution: A Osteosarcoma is of two types Primary osteosarcoma occurs in 2nd decade (75% incidence) Secondary osteosarcoma occurs in 5th to 6th decade (25% incidence)

questions.text: True statement regarding Mseleni joint disease is:
questions.solution: D Mseleni disorder is a rare crippling disorder which presents with chondrodysplasias. They are reported in northern Kwazulu Natal area in South Africa. This disorder has bilateral uniform arthropathy affecting mainly hip characteristically . It can also affect knee, angle, shoulder, elbow. Symptoms include pain, stiffness, difficulty in walking, short stature.

questions.text: Ankle X-ray image (lower end of tibia) of an adolescent boy is shown> Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chondromyxoid Fibromas are rare, benign, chondrogenic lesions characterized by variable amounts of chondroid, fibromatoid, and myxoid elements that are most commonly found in the metaphysis of long bones. Patients typically present between the ages of 10 and 30 with regional pain and swelling. Diagnosis is made with biopsy showing hypercellular area with lobules of fibromyxoid tissue and myxoid stroma with stellate cells. Treatment is usually intralesional curettage and bone grafting (or PMMA).

questions.text: The following type of amputation has traditionally been indicated for blind patients with bilateral below elbow amputations
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KRUKENBERG PROCEDURE: Krukenberg described a technique that converts a forearm stump into a pincer that is motorized by the pronator teres muscle • Indications: bilateral upper-extremity amputations • Not recommended as a primary procedure at the time of an amputation • The ulna and radius must extend distal to the majority of the pronator teres (the - motor for pinching and an elbow flexin contracture of less than 70

questions.text: Gallow’s traction is used for ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gallow’s traction, also known as Bryant’s traction, is a form of skin traction primarily used in young children — typically under the age of 2 years or weighing less than 12–14 kg — for the management of fracture shaft of the femur. In this technique, both legs are suspended vertically at a 90-degree angle from the hips, allowing the child’s body weight to provide the counter-traction needed to align the fractured femur. This method is particularly suitable for infants and toddlers, whose smaller size and lighter weight make skin traction effective and safe. It is important to note that Gallow’s traction is not used for fracture neck of femur, which requires more rigid immobilization and is usually managed by surgical fixation or spica casting, depending on the age. In adults, fracture neck of femur is treated surgically and sometimes temporarily managed with Buck’s traction, not Gallow’s. Therefore, Gallow’s traction is specifically indicated for fracture shaft of femur in very young children.

questions.text: Jersey finger is seen in rupture of?
questions.solution: A Jersey finger is a traumatic rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon at its point of attachment to the distal phalanx. This injury often occurs in American football when a player grabs another player's jersey with the tips of one or more fingers while that player is pulling or running away.

questions.solution: ABCD Ref: Maheshwari 5th Ed Explanation: Treatment of supracondylar fracture humerus in children Undisplaced #: POP immobilization for 3 weeks Angulated # with posterior cortex in continuity: Closed reduction under anesthesia, followed by percutaneous pinning Completely displaced #: Closed reduction under anesthesia, followed by percutaneous pinning. If fails, go for open reduction Compound # or vascular injury: Open reduction Lateral condylar fracture of humerus is known as fracture of necessity since it often progresses to non-union and needs anatomical reduction and surgical fixation. questions.text: Compartment syndrome commonly seen with which fracture(s)?
questions.solution: Ans: A, C, D Injuries with a high risk of developing compartment syndrome are as follows : - Supracondylar fracture of humerus - Forearm bone fractures - Closed tibial fractures - Crush injuries to leg & forearm Treatment: - Limb elevation - Active finger movements - Fasciotomy : The deep fascia of the compartment is slit longitudinally - Fibulectomy : The middle third of the fibula is excised in order to decompresses all compartments of the leg .

questions.text: True about osteitis fibrosa cystica?
questions.solution: B,C Abnormalities affecting the parathyroid glands cause a surplus of PTH, which, in turn, increases the activity and frequency of osteoclasts and osteocytes.Increased PTH levels trigger the release of stored calcium through the dissolution of old bone, as well as the conservation of serum calcium through a cessation in the production of new bone.

questions.text: A man with history of trauma 2 months ago presented with pain in his leg and with the following X-ray. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) OSTEOSARCOM • Highly malignant tumour with male predominance • Most common site is : distal femoral metaphysis • Two types of osteosarcoma are seen a. primary: occurs in second decade. It is the most common type. b. Secondary: occurs in 6th to 7th decade. It is preceeded by presence of pre-malignant lesion. Most common premalignant lesion is paget’s disease • Clinical symptoms: pain, pathological bone • Xray features: sunray appearance, codman’s triangle. • Most common site of metastasis is lung. • Bone to bone mets are also seen • Management is by neoadjuvant chemotheraphy.

questions.text: All of the following point towards intra-articular pathology except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) An intraarticular fracture is a bone fracture in which the break crosses into the surface of a joint. This always results in damage to the cartilage. Compared to extraarticular fractures, intraarticular have a higher risk for developing long-term complications, such as posttraumatic osteoarthritis.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Layers dissected in fasciotomy are • Skin • Subcutaneous fat • Superficial fascia • Deep fascia is cut till muscles pop out

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The fallen fragment sign refers to the presence of a bone fracture fragment resting dependently in a cystic bone lesion. This finding is said to be pathognomonic for a simple (unicameral) bone cyst following a pathological fracture. Although it has occasionally been reported with other cystic lesions, e.g. eosinophilic granuloma. The finding exists because a simple bone cyst is fluid filled, and therefore a bony fragment may descend through the fluid uninhibited. In contrast, the common differential lesions for a pathologic fracture through a lucent bone lesion (such as a lytic tumor, fibrous dysplasia, aneurysmal bone cyst or enchondroma) have a solid interior matrix and therefore would not permit such downward fragment migration.

questions.text: Most common cause of Non-purulent multi focal osteomyelitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteitis (SAPHO) syndrome is a rare chronic inflammatory disorder of bone, joint, and skin characterized by synovitis, osteitis, hyperostosis, and enthesitis, typically with pain, swelling, and tenderness in affected areas.

choices.text: Dislocation of other carpels with lunate in place

questions.text: Peri-lunate dislocation is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Perilunate dislocations and perilunate fracture-dislocations are potentially devastating closed wrist injuries that are often missed on initial imaging. These injuries involve dislocation of the carpus relative to the lunate which remains in normal alignment with the distal radius. They should not be confused with lunate dislocations where the lunate is dislocated in a volar direction and no longer has normal radiolunate articulation. Typical history is of a fall onto a dorsiflexed wrist. There may or may not be obvious clinical deformity. Occasionally median nerve injury, arterial compromise or compartment syndrome may be evident due to the dislocation. The majority of cases involve dorsal dislocation of the capitate and carpus relative to the lunate which remains in near-normal alignment with the radius. Volar perilunate dislocation is rare

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid fracture is most susseptible to avascular necrosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The scaphoid receives blood supply from the distal branches of radial artery, primarily to the mid and distal poles. The proximal pole receives retrograde blood supply. The peculiar blood supply of the scaphoid means, on the slightest hint of vascular compromise, the proximal pole is most susceptible to ischemia. The fracture in this instance enables the vascular compromise to happen. Types of Scaphoid Fracture: - Fracture of waist of Scaphoid (most common) - Fracture of distal 1/3 rd ( most common in children) - Fracture of proximal 1/3 rd : Highest chances of Avascular necrosis & non-union.

questions.text: Pott’s puffy tumour is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pott puffy tumor refers to a non-neoplastic complication of acute sinusitis. It is characterized by a primarily subgaleal collection, subperiosteal abscess, and osteomyelitis. It is usually related to the frontal sinus but is sometimes secondary to mastoid pathology. Radiographic features CT CT typically demonstrates an opacified frontal sinus with stranding and swelling of the overlying scalp. Bone algorithm will often demonstrate a defect in the anterior wall of the sinus. Contrast may demonstrate a focal abscess, and may also allow intracranial complications to be better delineated. MRI Subtle intracranial involvement is more easily seen at MR imaging. With the injection of gadolinium-based contrast material, one may see early linear enhancement of the dura mater, an extra-axial fluid collection, or an area of cerebritis or focal cerebral abscess formation. In the scalp, peripheral or rim contrast enhancement may be seen when an organized fluid collection is present. Treatment and prognosis Treatment is typically surgical with drainage of the abscess and at least 6 weeks of intravenous antibiotics.

questions.text: Scissoring gait is seen in which of the following condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the pathology shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The image shown above is Giant cell tumour. GIANT CELL TUMOUR • Occurs in skeletally mature. • Peak age is 20 to 40 years with female predominance. • Most common site is distal femur. ( epiphysis) • Locally invasive and aggressive tumours. • <5% malignant • <5% pulmonary mets • Classical features: Egg shell cracking, Epiphyseal, Eccentric, Expansile (gross and assymetrical) • Xray: geographical destruction, soap bubble appearance. • Biopsy: multinucleate giant cells with stroma of mononuclear cells.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of this 65 yr old ldy who presents with backache and following radiograph of spine is shown in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteoporosis is a metabolic skeletal disease defined as a reduction of bone mineral density below a defined lower limit of normal. Decreased bone density can be appreciated by decreased cortical thickness and loss of bony trabeculae in the early stages in radiography. Bones like the vertebra, long bones (proximal femur), calcaneum and tubular bones are usually looked at for evidence of osteoporosis. Nevertheless, dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is the gold standard of diagnosing osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following attitude will be seen in a patient with posterior dislocation of hip?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Explanation: Attitudes in different hip dislocations • Posterior dislocation: flexion, adduction, internal rotation • Anterior dislocation: flexion, abduction, external rotation

questions.text: Most common joint involved in septic arthritis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Most common site of septic arthritis a. Overall: staph. Aureus b. Sexually active group: gonococcus • Most common route: hematogenous • Most common site is : knee> hip

questions.text: In Painful arc sundrome , pain is felt during
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Shoulder impingement syndrome is a syndrome involving tendonitis (inflammation of tendons) of the rotator cuff muscles as they pass through the subacromial space, the passage beneath the acromion. It is particularly associated with tendonitis of the supraspinatus muscle. This can result in pain, weakness, and loss of movement at the shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brodie abscess is an intraosseous abscess related to a focus of subacute pyogenic osteomyelitis. Unfortunately, there is no reliable way radiographically to exclude a focus of osteomyelitis. It has a protean radiographic appearance and can occur at any location and in a patient of any age. It might or might not be expansile, have a sclerotic or nonsclerotic border, or have associated periostitis. Radiographic features Plain radiograph lytic lesion often in an oval configuration that is oriented along the long axis of the bone surrounded by a thick dense rim of reactive sclerosis that fades imperceptibly into surrounding bone lucent tortuous channel extending toward growth plate prior to physeal closure (pathognomonic) periosteal new-bone formation +/- adjacent soft-tissue swelling may persist for many months CT central intramedullary hypodense cystic lesion with thick rim ossification extensive thick well-circumscribed periosteal reaction and bone sclerosis around the lesion could be seen MRI The “penumbra sign” on magnetic resonance (MR) imaging is useful for discriminating subacute osteomyelitis from other bone lesions. The penumbra sign is a rim lining of an abscess cavity with higher signal intensity than that of the main abscess on T1-weighted images with strongly and rapidly enhance after contrast.

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by injury to which nerve involvement
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) No explanation is given so pls add: - Sciatic nerve consists of two distinct anatomical components: A) Tibial Nerve component B) Common Peroneal nerve component Tibial Nerve is in the centre of Sciatic nerve while the common Peroneal nerve is in the Peripheral of Sciatic nerve. So common Peroneal nerve component is most likely to be injured during Sciatic nerve injury . Common Peroneal nerve wraps around the neck of fibula where it is likely to get injured during fracture. Common Peroneal nerve supplies Ankle dorsiflexors , toes Extensors and evertors of foot . So when Peroneal nerve is injured , foot will go into plantar flexion & inversion. This is known as foot drop. The deformity will get as Equino Varus deformity. When such a patient walks , he drags the toes along the grounds . So while walking patient has to lift the foot high in order to clear the ground . This is known as high step Gait .
